questions.question_text: What is Direct Current (d.c.)?

options.label: A
options.text: Current whose magnitude and direction change periodically.

options.label: B
options.text: Current of constant magnitude flowing in one direction.

options.label: C
options.text: Current that flows only in metals.

options.label: D
options.text: Current produced only by batteries.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a source of direct current?

options.label: A
options.text: Mains electricity

options.label: B
options.text: A.C. Generator

options.label: C
options.text: Electric cell

options.label: D
options.text: Transformer

questions.question_text: A student claims: 'A dry cell provides alternating current because it has positive and negative terminals.' What is the flaw in this statement?

options.label: A
options.text: A dry cell provides d.c., which is constant in magnitude and direction, not a.c.

options.label: B
options.text: A dry cell has no terminals.

options.label: C
options.text: A dry cell provides current only in pulses.

options.label: D
options.text: The statement is correct; a cell provides a.c.

questions.question_text: In a torch, which component acts as the source of direct current?

options.label: A
options.text: The bulb

options.label: B
options.text: The switch

options.label: C
options.text: The cell(s)

options.label: D
options.text: The reflector

questions.question_text: How does the energy transformation in a cell differ from that in a power station generator (for mains)?

options.label: A
options.text: Cell: Chemical to Electrical; Generator: Mechanical to Electrical (often).

options.label: B
options.text: Both transform chemical energy to electrical energy.

options.label: C
options.text: Cell: Electrical to Heat; Generator: Mechanical to Heat.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no energy transformation in a cell.

questions.question_text: Why is the current from a cell considered 'direct'?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it flows directly from the source to the load without wires.

options.label: B
options.text: Because its magnitude remains constant for a long time and it flows in one direction (positive to negative externally).

options.label: C
options.text: Because it can flow in both directions.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is generated directly from sunlight.

questions.question_text: What is a primary cell?

options.label: A
options.text: A cell that can be recharged and reused.

options.label: B
options.text: A cell with a reversible chemical reaction.

options.label: C
options.text: A cell that provides current from an irreversible chemical reaction and is discarded after use.

options.label: D
options.text: The first cell invented by scientists.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a secondary cell?

options.label: A
options.text: Dry cell

options.label: B
options.text: Leclanche cell

options.label: C
options.text: Lead accumulator

options.label: D
options.text: Simple voltaic cell

questions.question_text: A student thinks both primary and secondary cells can be recharged. What is the key difference?

options.label: A
options.text: Primary cells have reversible reactions and can be recharged; secondary cells cannot.

options.label: B
options.text: Secondary cells have reversible reactions and can be recharged; primary cells have irreversible reactions and cannot be recharged.

options.label: C
options.text: Both can be recharged, but primary cells are cheaper.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither can be recharged.

questions.question_text: Where would you typically use a lead accumulator?

options.label: A
options.text: In a wristwatch

options.label: B
options.text: In a car battery

options.label: C
options.text: In a TV remote

options.label: D
options.text: In a torch

questions.question_text: Compare the energy transformation during 'charging' and 'discharging' of a secondary cell.

options.label: A
options.text: Charging: Electrical → Chemical; Discharging: Chemical → Electrical.

options.label: B
options.text: Charging: Chemical → Electrical; Discharging: Electrical → Chemical.

options.label: C
options.text: Both involve only chemical to electrical transformation.

options.label: D
options.text: Both involve only electrical to heat transformation.

questions.question_text: Why are secondary cells also called 'storage cells'?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they store electrical energy directly in wires.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they store chemical energy during charging, which is later converted to electrical energy.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are used to store water.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have a larger physical size for storage.

concepts.concept_name: Electric Current as Rate of Flow of Charge

questions.question_text: Electric current is defined as:

options.label: A
options.text: The total charge present in a conductor.

options.label: B
options.text: The rate of flow of electric charge.

options.label: C
options.text: The speed of electrons in a wire.

options.label: D
options.text: The potential difference per unit charge.

questions.question_text: What is the formula for current (I) if charge Q flows in time t?

options.label: A
options.text: I = Q * t

options.label: B
options.text: I = Q / t

options.label: C
options.text: I = t / Q

options.label: D
options.text: I = Q + t

questions.question_text: A student calculates current as I = t/Q. What is the error?

options.label: A
options.text: Current is charge divided by time, not time divided by charge.

options.label: B
options.text: Current is charge multiplied by time.

options.label: C
options.text: The formula is correct for alternating current.

options.label: D
options.text: The formula needs the square of time.

questions.question_text: If 10 coulombs of charge pass through a conductor in 5 seconds, what is the current?

options.label: B
options.text: 2 A

questions.key_concept: Calculating current from charge and time

questions.question_text: Compare the charge carriers in metallic conductors and in electrolytes.

options.label: A
options.text: Metals: free electrons only; Electrolytes: both positive and negative ions.

options.label: B
options.text: Both have free electrons as charge carriers.

options.label: C
options.text: Metals: ions; Electrolytes: electrons.

options.label: D
options.text: Both have only positive ions as charge carriers.

questions.question_text: If 6.25 x 10^18 electrons pass a point per second, what is the current? (Charge on electron = 1.6 x 10^-19 C)
What is the S.I. unit of electric current?

options.label: A
options.text: Volt

options.label: B
options.text: Ampere

options.label: C
options.text: Coulomb

options.label: D
options.text: Ohm

questions.question_text: 1 ampere is defined as:

options.label: A
options.text: 1 coulomb per second.

options.label: B
options.text: 1 joule per coulomb.

options.label: C
options.text: 1 volt per ohm.

options.label: D
options.text: 1 coulomb per volt.

questions.question_text: A student writes the unit of current as 'C/s' and claims it is called 'Columbus'. What is the correct name?

options.label: A
options.text: The unit is 'Coulomb-second'.

options.label: B
options.text: C/s is the unit, and its correct name is 'Ampere'.

options.label: C
options.text: The unit is 'Volt'.

options.label: D
options.text: The unit is 'Ohm'.

questions.question_text: Which of the following represents a unit for measuring very small currents?

options.label: A
options.text: kiloampere (kA)

options.label: B
options.text: microampere (μA)

options.label: C
options.text: megavolt (MV)

options.label: D
options.text: milliohm (mΩ)

questions.question_text: Compare the magnitudes: 1 mA, 1 A, and 1 μA.

options.label: A
options.text: 1 A > 1 mA > 1 μA

options.label: B
options.text: 1 μA > 1 mA > 1 A

options.label: C
options.text: 1 mA > 1 A > 1 μA

options.label: D
options.text: All are equal.

questions.question_text: Why is the ampere considered a fundamental unit, while the coulomb is a derived unit?

options.label: A
options.text: Ampere measures current, which is a base quantity; coulomb (charge) is derived from current and time (C = A*s).

options.label: B
options.text: Ampere is derived from volt and ohm.

options.label: C
options.text: Coulomb is a base unit, ampere is derived.

options.label: D
options.text: Both are fundamental units.

questions.question_text: What does the symbol consisting of two vertical lines, one longer (+) and one shorter (-), represent?

options.label: A
options.text: Ammeter

options.label: B
options.text: Voltmeter

options.label: C
options.text: Cell

options.label: D
options.text: Resistor

questions.question_text: Which symbol represents a closed key (switch)?

options.label: A
options.text: A circle with a sine wave inside

options.label: B
options.text: A circle with the letter 'A'

options.label: C
options.text: A line with a gap

options.label: D
options.text: A line with a dot (or no break)

questions.question_text: A student confuses the symbols for ammeter and voltmeter. How are they distinguished?

options.label: A
options.text: Ammeter symbol has 'V', voltmeter has 'A'.

options.label: B
options.text: Ammeter symbol is a circle with 'A'; voltmeter is a circle with 'V'.

options.label: C
options.text: Both are represented by a circle with 'G'.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference in their symbols.

questions.question_text: In a circuit diagram, which component's symbol would you use to indicate a device for varying resistance smoothly?

options.label: A
options.text: A fixed resistor (box)

options.label: B
options.text: A rheostat (arrow through resistor)

options.label: C
options.text: A cell

options.label: D
options.text: A galvanometer

questions.question_text: Compare the symbols for an a.c. source and a d.c. source (cell).

options.label: A
options.text: d.c. source: two lines (+ longer); a.c. source: circle with sine wave.

options.label: B
options.text: d.c. source: circle with sine wave; a.c. source: two lines.

options.label: C
options.text: Both use the same symbol.

options.label: D
options.text: d.c. source: circle with 'A'; a.c. source: circle with 'V'.

questions.key_concept: Symbols for a.c. and d.c. sources

questions.question_text: Why is the symbol for a galvanometer a circle with 'G', while an ammeter has 'A'?

options.label: A
options.text: Galvanometer detects current and direction but doesn't measure magnitude quantitatively; ammeter measures magnitude.

options.label: B
options.text: They are the same instrument with different names.

options.label: C
options.text: Galvanometer is for voltage, ammeter for current.

options.label: D
options.text: Galvanometer has higher resistance.

questions.question_text: What is the function of an ammeter?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure potential difference.

options.label: B
options.text: To measure the magnitude of current flowing in a circuit.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a source of current.

options.label: D
options.text: To vary the resistance in a circuit.

questions.question_text: How is an ammeter connected in a circuit?

options.label: A
options.text: In parallel with the component.

options.label: B
options.text: In series with the circuit.

options.label: C
options.text: Across the terminals of the cell.

options.label: D
options.text: It can be connected anywhere, no specific rule.

questions.question_text: A student connects an ammeter in parallel across a bulb to measure current through it. What will be the consequence?

options.label: A
options.text: It will correctly measure the current through the bulb.

options.label: B
options.text: It will create a short circuit, potentially damaging the ammeter because its resistance is very low.

options.label: C
options.text: It will measure the voltage across the bulb.

options.label: D
options.text: The bulb will glow brighter.

questions.question_text: In a circuit with a cell, key, and a resistor, where should the ammeter be placed to measure the total current?

options.label: A
options.text: In series, anywhere in the main loop (e.g., between cell and key).

options.label: B
options.text: Across the terminals of the resistor.

options.label: C
options.text: Next to the cell, not connected.

options.label: D
options.text: In parallel with the key.

questions.key_concept: Placement of ammeter in simple circuit

questions.question_text: Compare the ideal internal resistance of an ammeter and a voltmeter.

options.label: A
options.text: Ammeter: very low; Voltmeter: very high.

options.label: B
options.text: Ammeter: very high; Voltmeter: very low.

options.label: C
options.text: Both should have very high resistance.

options.label: D
options.text: Both should have very low resistance.

questions.question_text: Why must an ammeter have a very low resistance?

options.label: A
options.text: So that it does not significantly alter the total resistance of the circuit and thus the current being measured.

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure it can withstand high voltages.

options.label: C
options.text: To allow it to be connected in parallel.

options.label: D
options.text: To generate heat for its operation.

questions.key_concept: Reason for low resistance of ammeter

questions.question_text: What is the function of a voltmeter?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure current.

options.label: B
options.text: To measure potential difference between two points.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a variable resistance.

options.label: D
options.text: To detect the presence of current.

questions.question_text: How is a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across a resistor?

options.label: A
options.text: In series with the resistor.

options.label: B
options.text: In parallel across the resistor.

options.label: C
options.text: In series with the cell.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not connected to the circuit.

questions.question_text: A student connects a voltmeter in series with a bulb to measure the voltage across it. What will happen?

options.label: A
options.text: It will correctly measure the voltage.

options.label: B
options.text: Due to its high resistance, it will allow very little current, the bulb may not glow, and the reading will not be the voltage across the bulb alone.

options.label: C
options.text: It will measure the current through the bulb.

options.label: D
options.text: It will cause a short circuit.

questions.question_text: To measure the potential difference across a cell, a voltmeter should be connected:

options.label: A
options.text: In series with the cell.

options.label: B
options.text: Directly across the terminals of the cell (in parallel).

options.label: C
options.text: In series with the key.

options.label: D
options.text: It cannot measure a cell's potential difference.

questions.question_text: Compare the way an ammeter and a voltmeter draw current from the circuit.

options.label: A
options.text: Ammeter draws the entire circuit current (as it's in series); voltmeter draws negligible current (due to high resistance).

options.label: B
options.text: Voltmeter draws large current; ammeter draws negligible current.

options.label: C
options.text: Both draw large currents.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither draws any current.

questions.question_text: Why must a voltmeter have a very high resistance?

options.label: A
options.text: So that it draws very little current from the circuit, ensuring the measured potential difference is not significantly altered.

options.label: B
options.text: To allow it to measure high currents.

options.label: C
options.text: To protect it from high voltages.

options.label: D
options.text: To generate a magnetic field for its operation.

questions.key_concept: Reason for high resistance of voltmeter

questions.question_text: What is the primary function of a galvanometer?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure the exact magnitude of current.

options.label: B
options.text: To detect the presence and direction of a weak current.

options.label: C
options.text: To measure potential difference accurately.

options.label: D
options.text: To provide a source of current.

questions.question_text: How is a galvanometer connected in a circuit?

options.label: A
options.text: In parallel

options.label: B
options.text: In series

options.label: C
options.text: Across the cell terminals

options.label: D
options.text: It is not connected.

questions.question_text: A student uses a galvanometer to find the exact value of a 2 A current. Why is this not appropriate?

options.label: A
options.text: Galvanometers are only for a.c., not d.c.

options.label: B
options.text: Galvanometers are for detection and direction, not precise quantitative measurement of magnitude; an ammeter should be used.

options.label: C
options.text: Galvanometers can only measure voltage.

options.label: D
options.text: 2 A is too small a current for any instrument.

questions.question_text: In an experiment to test if a circuit is complete, which instrument is most suitable?

options.label: A
options.text: Voltmeter

options.label: B
options.text: Galvanometer

options.label: C
options.text: Ammeter

options.label: D
options.text: Rheostat

questions.question_text: Compare the zero mark and scale of a galvanometer with that of an ammeter.

options.label: A
options.text: Galvanometer: zero at center, shows direction; Ammeter: zero at one end, shows magnitude.

options.label: B
options.text: Both have zero at one end.

options.label: C
options.text: Both have zero at center.

options.label: D
options.text: Ammeter has zero at center, galvanometer at one end.

questions.key_concept: Scale design of galvanometer vs ammeter

questions.question_text: Why does a galvanometer not have + and - marked on its terminals like an ammeter or voltmeter?

options.label: A
options.text: Because current can enter through either terminal; the direction of deflection indicates the direction of current flow.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is always connected incorrectly.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it measures only magnitude, not direction.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a very old instrument.

questions.question_text: What is the simplest electric circuit mentioned in the chapter?

options.label: A
options.text: Cell, ammeter, voltmeter, rheostat

options.label: B
options.text: Cell, bulb, and switch

options.label: C
options.text: Cell, resistor, galvanometer

options.label: D
options.text: Battery, motor, fuse

questions.question_text: In a simple circuit with a cell, bulb, and key, what happens when the key is open?

options.label: A
options.text: The bulb glows brightly.

options.label: B
options.text: The bulb does not glow.

options.label: C
options.text: The cell gets discharged instantly.

options.label: D
options.text: The bulb glows dimly.

questions.question_text: A student builds a circuit with a cell, wires, and a bulb, but the bulb does not glow. He concludes the cell is dead. What other simple possibility could it be?

options.label: A
options.text: The circuit might be open (incomplete connection, loose wire, or broken filament).

options.label: B
options.text: The bulb is designed not to glow.

options.label: C
options.text: The wires are too thick.

options.label: D
options.text: Light is invisible.

questions.key_concept: Open circuit as cause of bulb not glowing

questions.question_text: In a circuit with a cell, key, rheostat, and bulb, what happens to the bulb's brightness when the rheostat's resistance is increased?

options.label: A
options.text: Brightness increases.

options.label: B
options.text: Brightness decreases.

options.label: C
options.text: Brightness remains the same.

options.label: D
options.text: The bulb fuses.

questions.key_concept: Effect of resistance on current and brightness

questions.question_text: Compare the roles of a 'key' and a 'rheostat' in controlling a circuit.

options.label: A
options.text: Key: makes or breaks the circuit (on/off); Rheostat: varies the current smoothly (dimmer).

options.label: B
options.text: Key: varies current; Rheostat: turns circuit on/off.

options.label: C
options.text: Both are used to turn the circuit on/off.

options.label: D
options.text: Both are used to measure current.

questions.question_text: In a circuit diagram, components are shown connected by lines. What do these lines represent, and what property should they ideally have?

options.label: A
options.text: They represent connecting wires, which should have negligible resistance.

options.label: B
options.text: They represent air gaps, which should have high resistance.

options.label: C
options.text: They represent resistors, which should have precise resistance.

options.label: D
options.text: They represent the path of light, which should be transparent.

questions.key_concept: Meaning of connecting lines in circuit diagram

questions.question_text: What are conductors?

options.label: A
options.text: Substances that do not allow current to flow.

options.label: B
options.text: Substances that allow current to flow easily.

options.label: C
options.text: Substances that store electric charge.

options.label: D
options.text: Substances that produce light when current flows.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an insulator?

options.label: A
options.text: Copper

options.label: B
options.text: Rubber

options.label: C
options.text: Aluminium

options.label: D
options.text: Mercury

questions.question_text: A student says 'Pure water is a good conductor of electricity.' Why is this statement incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Pure water has very few ions, so it is a poor conductor (insulator); impure/acidulated water conducts.

options.label: B
options.text: Pure water is the best conductor known.

options.label: C
options.text: Water can only conduct in solid state (ice).

options.label: D
options.text: The statement is correct.

questions.key_concept: Conductivity of pure vs impure water

questions.question_text: Why are electric wires covered with a layer of plastic or rubber?

options.label: A
options.text: To make them look colorful.

options.label: B
options.text: To provide insulation and prevent electric shocks.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase their resistance.

options.label: D
options.text: To help them conduct better.

questions.question_text: Compare the number of free electrons in a typical conductor and an insulator.

options.label: A
options.text: Conductor: large number; Insulator: very few/negligible.

options.label: B
options.text: Conductor: very few; Insulator: large number.

options.label: C
options.text: Both have large numbers.

options.label: D
options.text: Both have very few.

questions.key_concept: Free electron density in conductors vs insulators

questions.question_text: Why is the human body considered a conductor of electricity?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the body contains fluids (like blood) which are ionic solutions and can conduct electricity.

options.label: B
options.text: Because bones are good insulators.

options.label: C
options.text: Because skin is a perfect insulator.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the body produces its own electricity.

questions.question_text: What is a closed circuit?

options.label: A
options.text: A circuit with a break, preventing current flow.

options.label: B
options.text: A complete path that allows current to flow.

options.label: C
options.text: A circuit with only a cell and no other components.

options.label: D
options.text: A circuit that is always shorted.

questions.question_text: Which of the following will create an open circuit?

options.label: A
options.text: A closed switch

options.label: B
options.text: An unbroken metal wire

options.label: C
options.text: A broken filament in a bulb

options.label: D
options.text: A conducting path from cell to bulb

questions.question_text: A student thinks that if a circuit has a cell connected to a bulb with metal wires, it is always closed. What condition could still make it open?

options.label: A
options.text: If the bulb's filament is broken or if there is a loose connection, the path is incomplete, making it open.

options.label: B
options.text: It is impossible for such a circuit to be open.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if the cell is removed.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if the wires are too long.

questions.question_text: In a torch, when you slide the switch to 'ON', what happens to the circuit?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes an open circuit.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes a closed circuit.

options.label: C
options.text: It becomes a parallel circuit.

options.label: D
options.text: The cell is removed.

questions.question_text: Compare the state of a circuit when the key is open vs when a conductor in the path is replaced by an insulator.

options.label: A
options.text: Both result in an open circuit, preventing current flow.

options.label: B
options.text: Open key: closed circuit; Insulator: closed circuit.

options.label: C
options.text: Open key: allows current; Insulator: stops current.

options.label: D
options.text: Open key: stops current; Insulator: allows current.

questions.key_concept: Different ways to create an open circuit

questions.question_text: Why does current not flow in an open circuit?

options.label: A
options.text: Because there is no complete path for electrons to flow from the negative terminal to the positive terminal of the source.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the voltage becomes zero.

options.label: C
options.text: Because resistance becomes infinite in a closed circuit.

options.label: D
options.text: Because electrons are destroyed.

questions.key_concept: Reason for no current in open circuit
